question:
For a positive integer $m,$ let $f(m) = m^2 + m + 1$.  Find the largest positive integer $n$ such that
\[1000 f(1^2) f(2^2) \dotsm f(n^2) \ge f(1)^2 f(2)^2 \dotsm f(n)^2.\]
answer:
Note that $f(k^2) = k^4 + k^2 + 1.$  By a little give and take,
\begin{align*}
f(k^2) &= (k^4 + 2k^2 + 1) - k^2 \\
&= (k^2 + 1)^2 - k^2 \\
&= (k^2 + k + 1)(k^2 - k + 1) \\
&= f(k) (k^2 - k + 1).
\end{align*}Furthermore,
\[f(k - 1) = (k - 1)^2 + (k - 1) + 1 = k^2 - 2k + 1 + k - 1 = k^2 - k + 1,\]so
\[f(k^2) = f(k) f(k - 1).\]Thus, the given inequality becomes
\[1000 f(1) f(0) \cdot f(2) f(1) \cdot f(3) f(2) \dotsm f(n - 1) f(n - 2) \cdot f(n) f(n - 1) \ge f(1)^2 f(2)^2 \dotsm f(n)^2,\]which simplifies to
\[1000 \ge f(n).\]The function $f(n)$ is increasing, and $f(31) = 993$ and $f(32) = 1057,$ so the largest such $n$ is $\boxed{31}.$
agents_response:
The inequality telescopes, so
\[f(1) f(2) \dotsm f(n) \le 1000 f(1^2) f(2^2) \dotsm f(n^2).\]
In other words,
\[(f(1) f(2) \dotsm f(n))^2 \le 1000^n f(1^2) f(2^2) \dotsm f(n^2).\]
Recall that $f(m) = m^2 + m + 1,$ so we can write
\begin{align*}
&\left( f(1) f(2) f(3) \dotsm f(n) \right)^2 \\
&= (2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm ((n - 1)^2 + n - 1 + 1))^2 \\
&= (2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm n^2)^2 \\
&= (2^2 \cdot 5^2 \cdot 12^2 \dotsm (n^2)^2.
\end{align*}We take the square root of both sides, and divide by $2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm n^2,$ to get
\begin{align*}
f(1) f(2) \dotsm f(n) &= 2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm ((n - 1)^2 + n - 1 + 1) \\
&= 2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm n^2 \\
&\le \sqrt{1000^n} \\
&= 10^{3n/2}.
\end{align*}We seek the largest possible value of $n$ such that this inequality is satisfied. Observe that
\begin{align*}
2 \cdot 5 \cdot 12 \dotsm n^2 &= 2^i \cdot 5^j \cdot 12^k \dotsm n^{2i} \\
&\le 10^{3n/2},
\end{align*}where $i,$ $j,$ $k$ are the exponents on 2, 5, 12, etc., respectively. Note that the exponents $i,$ $j,$ $k,$ etc. are all less than or equal to $n,$ and that the base 10 is obtained by multiplying two factors of 2 and one factor of 5. Therefore,
\begin{align*}
2^i \cdot 5^j \cdot 12^k \dotsm n^{2i} &\le 10^{3n/2} \\
2^i \cdot 5^{j/3} \cdot 12^{k/3} \dotsm n^{2i/3} &\le 10^n.
\end{align*}By observation, we see that the right-hand side can be decreased by factors of 2, 5, 12, 24, 60, etc. to slightly less than $10^n,$ which means that $n = \boxed{3}$ is the largest possible solution.
